entry.title: How to Migrate Existing Ariba Contracts and Sourcing Projects to a new Supplier ID
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We have a situation where we have multiple Supplier IDs present for the same Supplier. We would like to keep the system clean with only one supplier being active and other supplier IDs should be deactivated. This is only related to Sourcing and Contracts and we have SLP as well. Our Supplier Onboarding happens through SLP only.

Is there a way to move or update existing Ariba Contracts and Sourcing events (All statuses) to a new Supplier ID? Is this allowed, has anyone done this? If so, can someone please throw some light on this?

Any suggestion or guidance on this is much appreciated!

Thanks in Advance,

Velu

entry.title: Warehouse Management - Clear Negative Stock from 902 Stype
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I would like to request your assistance and guidance regarding an issue we are facing with negative stock appearing in storage type 902 due to a user error.

Scenario Overview:

  1. A Purchase Order was created with line item 10 (Material ABCX) and a PO quantity of 10.
  2. An inbound delivery was created, and the PGR was posted successfully. In the PO history, the 101 movement type with the material document is completed.
  3. The issue occurred when a second inbound delivery was mistakenly created and received with a quantity of 20, resulting in an additional 101 movement.
  4. Upon realizing the error, the user attempted to reverse the second material document, which posted a 102 movement.
  5. After this reversal, negative stock remains in storage type 902 under both ‚ÄúStock for Putaway‚Äù and ‚ÄúPick Quantity‚Äù columns. Please refer to the attachment.

Additional Notes:

The Purchase Order has no remaining open quantity to receive (Still to be Delivered = 0).  I checked LB13 and LT24 and found no open transfer orders or documents that can be processed.

At this point, I am looking for guidance on how to clear or flush out the negative stock from storage type 902 caused by this human error. I would greatly appreciate any advice, recommended steps, or corrective actions.

Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Re: SAP Analytics Cloud, add-in for Microsoft Excel - New high-volume mode
entry.content:
We should set aside the assumption that customers will not use planning layouts exceeding one million cells.
In fact, the more advanced and sophisticated the management capabilities of a customer are, the more complex their planning layouts tend to be often far beyond what we think.
We have already experienced cases where SAC could not accommodate customer requirements involving planning layouts of more than one million cells, and we ultimately had to propose BPC instead.
While there are still some limitations today particularly in planning, I Hope continuous improvements going forward.

entry.title: Output Management - How to send emails to mail-addresses from BUR001 relationship
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

in our scenario we have integrated S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with Sales Cloud V2. As stated in that KBA, V2 is not able to display the email-address of the business partner in the UI. To see and use the email addresses in V2, they have to be replicated via the relationships. Therefore we would have to maintain it on relationship-level in S/4.

The challenge we're facing is: In S/4 we need the email address on Business Partner level for the use in Output Management (we're using Y partner functions to send emails to the Contact Persons). 

To summarize: In V2 we need the mail addresses in another place than in S/4...

Has anyone an idea, if we could use a CDS-View in S/4 to use the mail-address from the relationship in Output Management? I know there's a BAdI APOC_ADD_EMAIL_RECIPIENTS which might help.

BR Tobi

entry.title: Customize emails for e-invoices sent via DRC Cloud Edition
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

we have integrated SAP DRC Cloud Edition with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

We want to send out e-invoices (ZUGFeRD) via email. The scenario works and the invoice is sent out.

But we would like to customize the email (subject, body) that is sent out (like we could do for other invoices that are sent out via Output Management directly from Public Cloud).

Does anybody know if that is even possible and if so, how?

BR Tobi

entry.title: manifest.json not picking yocc based extension

I doubt it's manifest.json which is not having correct entries. Can you please help resolve this issue.

My SAP Commerce cloud version is 2211.43.
These are my manifest entries for this new extension:

"useConfig": {
   "extensions": {
     "location": "config/localextensions.xml",
     ...
]
"aspects": [
   {
   "name": "backoffice",
   "webapps": [
   ...
   {
   "name": "commercewebservices",
   "contextPath": "/occ"
   }
]
},
{
   "name": "api",
   "webapps": [
   ...
   {
     "name": "commercewebservices",

entry.title: Re: Customize emails for e-invoices sent via DRC Cloud Ed...
entry.content:
Hi Tobi,

I had exactly the same issue. SAP does not provide an e-mail template for e-invoices like it does for the regular invoices sent via Output Management.

We solved it by implementing the BAdI _EDOC_PART_CONN_CHANGE_MAIL. With this BAdI you can add your own e-mail template text.

Hope that helps!

Best regards
David

entry.title: Spieglein, Spieglein - Einen Magischen Spiegel in Snap! Programmieren
entry.content:
In diesem Artikel befinden sich Videos, PDF-Material und Erweiterungs-Ideen f√ºr das Projekt Magischer Spiegel, bei dem mithilfe der in Snap! eingebauten Grafikeffekte Fotos oder Live-Bilder der Webcam verzerrt, gef√§rbt oder verwirbelt werden k√∂nnen. 

Das Projekt eignet sich sich gut zum Einstieg ins Programmieren, da es nur wenige Bl√∂cke ben√∂tigt. Es kann aufgrund der angewendeten Konzepte ab der Grundschule eingesetzt werden, findet aber durchaus auch bei √§lteren Zielgruppen Anklang üòâ. 

 

Teil 1: Grafikeffekte interaktiv auf ein Foto anwenden:

Grundidee dieses Teils ist es, mithilfe des setze _ Effekt auf _ Blocks das Kost√ºm eines Objekts interaktiv zu ver√§ndern. Daf√ºr kann entweder ein Foto mit der Webcam aufgenommen werden oder ein Bild vom Computer in Snap! importiert werden. 

  • Bild mit der Webcam aufnehmen: Auf die Webcam kann unter anderem vom Kost√ºme-Tab zugegriffen werden. Durch Klicken auf das Kamera-Symbol √∂ffnet sich ein Fenster, in dem die Webcam angezeigt wird. Um ein Webcam-Kost√ºm aufzunehmen, muss auf "Sichern" geklickt werden. "Abbrechen" schlie√üt das Webcam-Fenster. 
    Wird die Webcam zum ersten Mal mit Snap! verwendet, muss der Zugriff erlaubt werden. Je nach Browser erscheint ein Pop-Up Fenster, aus dem der Zugriff auf die Webcam gew√§hrt werden kann. Ist der Zugriff nicht erlaubt, ist der Webcam-Knopf ausgegraut. Dann kann die Seite einfach noch einmal geladen werden, damit erneut nach dem Zugriff gefragt wird. 
    Klicke auf den "Kost√ºme"-Tab und dort auf die Webcam, um die Kamera zu √∂ffnen (links), beim ersten Mal muss der Zugriff erlaubt werden (Mitte, Bild von Google Chrome, Pop-Up sieht je nach Browser unterschiedlich aus), dann kann durch Klicken auf "Sichern" ein Foto-Kost√ºm gemacht werden (rechts), "Abbrechen" schlie√üt das Fenster mit der Kamera.

 

  • Bild importieren: Wenn keine Webcam vorhanden ist, oder andere Bilder genutzt werden sollen, k√∂nnen auch einfach Bilder vom Computer importiert werden. Klicke daf√ºr auf das Dateimen√º und w√§hle Importieren... Es √∂ffnet sich ein Fenster, in dem du zum gew√ºnschten Bild navigieren kannst. 

 

Material f√ºr den ersten Teil des Projekts:

  • Diese Videoerkl√§rung f√ºhrt Schritt f√ºr Schritt durch das Programm:
    https://youtu.be/H9bsrODOqjs 
  • Diese Lernkarte erkl√§rt detailliert den Ablauf des Projekts:
    https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/YxtXrKn?rc=10&doi=SAP1265363 
  • Dieses Starterprojekt enth√§lt nur die ben√∂tigten Bl√∂cke f√ºr beide Teile des magischen Spiegels. Reduzierte Starterprojekte eignen sich besonders f√ºr den Einsatz mit j√ºngeren Kindern, da sie die kognitive Belastung reduzieren, aber auch die kreativen M√∂glichkeiten einschr√§nken: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Starter&editMode&noRun 
  • Dieses L√∂sungsprojekt enth√§lt das Programm f√ºr den ersten Teil des magischen Spiegels. Als Effekte wurden Farbe und Fischauge ausgew√§hlt. Das Projekt wird mit der gr√ºnen Fahne gestartet, Dr√ºcken der Leertaste setzt die Grafikeffekte zur√ºck. 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Solution%20-%20Part1 

 

Hinweis f√ºr die Nutzung mit Tablets:

Werden f√ºr das Programmieren oder Vorf√ºhren des Projekts Tablets genutzt, muss ein extra Schritt ausgef√ºhrt werden.

Am Computer kann die Maus x- bzw. Maus y- Position, √ºber die die Effekte gesteuert werden, immer ausgelesen werden. Bei Tablets ist das nur m√∂glich, wenn ein tats√§chliches Touch-Event stattfindet, d.h. der Finger oder ein Stift das Tablet ber√ºhrt. Damit ist dann auch immer ein Klick verbunden. 

F√ºhrt man diesen Klick auf dem Foto aus, hebt man das Objekt von der B√ºhne an und zieht es mit der Bewegung mit. Das kann verhindert werden, indem man das H√§kchen vor der Einstellung greifbar entfernt. Dann kann das Objekt nur noch programmatisch, nicht mehr durch Klicken mit der Maus entfernt werden. 

Ist das H√§kchen vor "greifbar" gesetzt, kann das Objekt mit Mausklick bewegt werden. Wird das H√§kchen entfernt, kann das Objekt nur noch durch das Programm selbst bewegt werden.

 

Teil 2: Magischen Spiegel mit Bewegtbild bauen:

Im zweiten Teil des Projekts wird die Webcam fortlaufend auf ein Kost√ºm projiziert. Dadurch entsteht der Eindruck eines Live-Video-Feeds auf dem Spiegel-Objekt. Dieser kann dann wieder mit den Grafikeffekten bearbeitet werden. 

 

Materialien f√ºr den zweiten Teil des Projekts:

  • In diesem Video findest du eine Schritt f√ºr Schritt Anleitung f√ºr den zweiten Teil:
    https://youtu.be/9moiIRrqPCI
  • Diese Lernkarte enth√§lt eine detaillierte Anleitung f√ºr das Projekt:
    https://d.dam.sap.com/a/Uao4FKG?rc=10&doi=SAP1265850 
  • Dieses L√∂sungsprojekt enth√§lt das gesamte Programm f√ºr Teil 2: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Solution%20-%20Part2 

 

Erweitere das Projekt:

Zus√§tzlich zu den eingebauten Grafikeffekten k√∂nnen weitere Ideen im Projekt umgesetzt werden. Die Bl√∂cke hierf√ºr sind nicht im Starterprojekt enthalten. So k√∂nnen Bl√∂cke ein- und ausgeblendet werden:

Um selbst Bl√∂cke zu verbergen, kannst du mit Rechtsklick auf die Palette klicken und die Option ‚ÄûBl√∂cke verbergen‚Ä¶‚Äú ausw√§hlen. Dadurch √∂ffnet sich ein Dialogfenster mit allen verf√ºgbaren Bl√∂cken.

Darin kannst du die Bl√∂cke, die du ausblenden m√∂chtest, einzeln ausw√§hlen, indem du das K√§stchen davor anklickst ‚Äì oder du machst einen Rechtsklick im Dialogfenster und w√§hlst die Option ‚Äûnicht verwendete‚Äú. Das ist besonders n√ºtzlich, wenn du nur die Bl√∂cke f√ºr ein bestimmtes Projekt brauchst: Du kannst einfach dein gew√ºnschtes Ergebnis bauen und anschlie√üend alle ungenutzten Bl√∂cke verbergen.

Nachdem du auf OK klickst, enth√§lt die Palette nur noch die nicht-ausgew√§hlten Bl√∂cke.

Falls du ausgeblendete Bl√∂cke wieder anzeigen m√∂chtest, kannst du erneut den Dialog ‚ÄûBl√∂cke verbergen...‚Äú √∂ffnen und das H√§kchen vor dem jeweiligen Block entfernen. M√∂chtest du alle Bl√∂cke anzeigen, kannst du im Dialogfenster mit Rechtsklick die Option "nichts" ausw√§hlen und dann auf OK klicken. 

Dadurch werden alle Bl√∂cke wieder in der Palette sichtbar.

 

Das Bild verzerren: 

Mithilfe des strecke-Blocks k√∂nnen die Kost√ºme eines Objekts verzerrt werden. Der strecke-Block hat drei Eingaben, das zu streckende Kost√ºm und die Streckung bzw. Stauchung in x- und y-Richtung. W√§hlt man f√ºr beide Richtungen 100 aus, passiert nichts, das Kost√ºm beh√§lt seine aktuelle Streckung bei. W√§hlt man f√ºr die x-Richtung Werte gr√∂√üer als 100 % (z.B. 200, s.u.) wird das Kost√ºm breiter. Bei Werten kleiner als 100% in x-Richtung w√ºrde es schmaler werden. Werte kleiner als 100% in y-Richtung machen das Kost√ºm flacher (z.B. 80, s.u.), bei Werten gr√∂√üer als 100% in y-Richtung w√ºrde das Kost√ºm h√∂her werden. 

links: Originalkost√ºm "Ei", rechts: Kost√ºm "Ei" gestreckt auf 200% in x-Richtung - daher breiter, und gestaucht auf 80% in y-Richtung - daher flacher.

Um das Bild der Webcam f√ºr den magischen Spiegel zu verzerren, muss noch ein kleiner Umweg gegangen werden. F√ºgt man statt dem Kost√ºm "Ei" n√§mlich direkt den Video Snap auf selbst ein, wird das Kost√ºm in diesem Fall immer breiter und flacher, da die Abmessungen des Objekts jedes Mal, wenn der Schnappschuss als Kost√ºm angezogen wird, auf x: 200% und y: 80% gestreckt bzw. gestaucht werden - in anderen Worten, bei jedem neuen Schnappschuss wird das Objekt doppelt so breit und 0.8 Mal so hoch wie vorher. 

Das Kost√ºm wird jedes Mal gestreckt, wenn der Webcam-Schnappschuss als Kost√ºm angezogen wird, wenn das Kost√ºm nicht vorher auf die Originalma√üe zur√ºckgesetzt wurde.

Bevor das Kost√ºm Video Snap auf selbst angezogen wird, sollte deshalb wieder zur√ºck auf das urspr√ºngliche Kost√ºm "Ei" gewechselt werden. Damit bleibt die Streckung dann immer bei x: 200%, y: 80% der Original-Ausma√üe. 

Bevor der Video Snap als Kost√ºm angezogen wird und auf x: 200% und y: 80% gestreckt bzw. gestaucht wird, wird auf das urspr√ºngliche Kost√ºm "Ei" gewechselt.

 

Das Bild spiegeln und duplizieren:

Ebenfalls mit dem strecke-Block kann das Kost√ºm auch in verschiedene Richtungen gespiegelt werden, wenn man negative Eingaben f√ºr die x- und y-Richtung w√§hlt. Ist die Eingabe f√ºr die x-Richtung beispielsweise -100% wird das Kost√ºm horizontal gespiegelt. Bei einer Streckung in y-Richtung von -100% wird es vertikal gespiegelt. 

links: Video Snap auf selbst, Mitte: Video Snap auf selbst, horizontal gespiegelt durch Streckung in x-Richtung auf -100%. rechts: Video Snap auf selbst vertikal gespiegelt durch Streckung in y-Richtung auf -100%

Nur das Spiegeln alleine ist noch nicht besonders interessant. Lustig wird es, wenn man gespiegelte und nicht gespiegelte Objekte √ºbereinander anzeigt.

Erstelle zwei Objekte und bewege sie an dieselbe Stelle. Das untere der beiden Objekte tr√§gt einfach dauerhaft den Video Snap auf selbst als Kost√ºm. Das obenliegende Objekt soll ebenfalls dauerhaft das Bild der Webcam als Kost√ºm tragen, aber horizontal oder vertikal gespiegelt. Dann kannst du mithilfe des Durchsichtigkeit-Effekts das obenliegende Objekt semi-transparent machen. Beide Versionen, die gespiegelte und nicht-gespiegelte sind nun gleichzeitig sichtbar. 

Du kannst leicht bis zu 4 verschieden gespiegelte Objekte √ºbereinander anzeigen, nur musst du dann den Durchsichtigkeit-Effekt f√ºr jedes Objekt dementsprechend anpassen. 

Zwei Objekte √ºbereinander, die beide jeweils dauerhaft den Video Snap auf selbst als Kost√ºm anziehen. Beim oberen Objekt ist das Kost√ºm in x-Richtung auf -100% gestreckt, also horizontal gespiegelt. Zus√§tzlich ist beim oberen Objekt der Durchsichtigkeitseffekt auf 50 gesetzt, dadurch sind beide Versionen, Original und horizontal gespiegeltes Kost√ºm gleichzeitig sichtbar.

 

Das Bild drehen:

Der magische Spiegel kann auch gedreht werden. Das Bild der Webcam wird dann jeweils in die Richtung angezeigt, in die das Objekt gerade gedreht ist. Zeigt das Objekt Richtung 90, ist es "richtig herum", d.h. der Hals ist unten. Setzt man die Richtung beispielsweise auf 45, ist das ganze Objekt und damit auch der Video Snap darauf um 45 Grad gedreht. Der Hals zeigt nun nach unten rechts. 

Um die Richtung immer zu √§ndern, kann zum Beispiel ein Skript genutzt werden, das das Objekt dauerhaft langsam dreht. 

Links: Video Snap wenn das Objekt Richtung 90 zeigt. Mitte: Video Snap wenn das Objekt Richtung 45 Grad zeigt. Rechts: Skript, mit dem sich das Objekt dauerhaft um 0.2 Grad dreht.

 

Die Erweiterungen ausprobieren:

links: mithilfe des "strecke" Blocks verzerrtes Spiegelbild, mitte: zwei Objekte √ºbereinander, das obere ist transparent (Durchsichtigkeit-Effekt 50) und mithilfe des "strecke" Blocks (x: - 100, y: 100) gespiegelt, rechts: das Objekt dreht sich langsam um 0.2 Grad , dadurch kann beispielsweise der Hals links an der Seite sein.

Teste die drei Erweiterungen im folgenden L√∂sungs-Projekt: 
https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=Magic%20Mirror%20Extension 

Dr√ºcke die gr√ºne Fahne, um alle Spiegel zu starten. Dann dr√ºcke die Taste der Spiegel-Nummer, um die jeweilige Erweiterung ein- und auszublenden.
Taste 1 f√ºr den Verzerrspiegel
Taste 2 f√ºr den "gespiegelten" Spiegel
Taste 3 f√ºr den drehenden Spiegel 

 

Exkurs: Die Webcam auf anderen Objekten anzeigen - Tipps, Tricks und weitere Ideen

Die Video Snap auf selbst Funktion gibt ein Bild zur√ºck, das den Teil der Webcam anzeigt, der sich hinter dem ausf√ºhrenden Objekt (selbst) befindet. Das Bild hat die Form des aktuellen Kost√ºms, egal ob das Kost√ºm selbst gemalt wurde oder aus der Kost√ºmbibliothek oder vom Computer importiert wurde. Das Ganze funktioniert auch, wenn die Videotransparenz auf 100 gesetzt wurde, die Webcam auf der B√ºhne also unsichtbar ist. 

Der Video Snap der Webcam wird auf dem Kost√ºm von Alonzo, das das Objekt tr√§gt, das die Funktion ausf√ºhrt, angezeigt.

Manchmal ist das Kost√ºm zu klein, um den gew√ºnschten Teil der Webcam anzuzeigen. In diesem Fall passt auf Alonzo nur ein Auge, nicht das gesamte Gesicht. Auch das Vergr√∂√üern des Objekts beispielsweise von Gr√∂√üe 100 auf Gr√∂√üe 250 ver√§ndert den Teil der Webcam nicht, der auf dem Objekt angezeigt wird. Genau wie das Objekt wird auch das Bild der Webcam auf dem Objekt vergr√∂√üert, der gezeigte Ausschnitt bleibt gleich.

links ist das Objekt in Gr√∂√üe 100 mit einem Video Snap Kost√ºm angezeigt. Rechts daneben dasselbe Objekt mit Gr√∂√üe 250. Dabei wird insgesamt alles vergr√∂√üert, der angezeigte Ausschnitt der Webcam bleibt beim Vergr√∂√üern des Objekts also gleich.

M√∂chtest du den Ausschnitt der Kamera vergr√∂√üern, musst du die Gr√∂√üe des Kost√ºms ver√§ndern, ohne die Gr√∂√üe des Objekts selbst anzupassen. Daf√ºr kannst du das Skript, das in der folgenden Grafik angezeigt wird verwenden. Am Skript, das die Webcam auf dem Objekt anzeigt, muss nichts ver√§ndert werden. 

Oben ist das Objekt in Gr√∂√üe 100 mit seinem Kost√ºm angezeigt. Rechts daneben ist das Ergebnis des ‚ÄúVideo Snap auf selbst‚Äù Blocks f√ºr dieses Objekt zu sehen. Unten ist dasselbe Objekt mit vergr√∂√üertem Kost√ºm zu sehen. Durch das links stehende Skript wird die Gr√∂√üe des Objekts zuerst auf 280 gesetzt. Dann wird es auf die B√ºhne gestempelt. Die Gr√∂√üe des Objekts wird danach auf 100 zur√ºckgesetzt. Die gestempelten Abdr√ºcke (Malspuren) k√∂nnen als Kost√ºm angezogen werden. Das Objekt hat nun eine Gr√∂√üe von 100 aber mit einem deutlich vergr√∂√üerten Kost√ºm. Dadurch wird auch der Ausschnitt der Webcam, der auf dem Kost√ºm angezeigt wird, ver√§ndert.

Damit stehen dir viele weitere Ideen aus dem Bereich Media Computation mit Bildern offen. Wie w√§re es beispielsweise mit eigenen Grafikeffekten, wie dem Negativ-Effekt, der die Farben invertiert. 
Schon von Dithering geh√∂rt? Dabei handelt es sich um eine Technik, bei der aus wenigen Farben (in diesem Fall einem einzigen Gr√ºnton) eine gr√∂√üere Farbtiefe erzeugt werden kann (in diesem Fall entsteht durch Punkte in unterschiedlicher Gr√∂√üe ein "Gr√ºnstufen" Effekt).
Oder wie w√§re es mit einer personalisierten Version des ber√ºhmten Kunstwerks "Schotter" von Georg Nees?

Werde selbst kreativ beziehungsweise wirf einen Blick auf die weiteren Materialien zum Thema Media Computation  üéº üìú üé•

entry.title: Re: Enable Posting of Supplier Invoices with Zero Amount
entry.content:
Dear @Chris1973 ,

Thank you for your follow-up.

To clarify the scenario: we are referring to a "Netting" or "Clearing" invoice where the document contains both Debit and Credit line items that mathematically offset each other, resulting in a final Gross Amount (Vendor Liability) of 0.00 EUR.

However, these line items are subject to VAT, and we need to record the tax information correctly in our VAT Registers, even if the payment amount is zero.

Here is the specific Double-Entry (Journal Entry) structure for this requirement:

Scenario: Invoice with Offsetting Items (e.g. Service Charge with immediate Full Rebate/Credit Memo)

Gross Invoice Amount (Vendor Line): 0.00 EUR

Posting Logic:

Debit [S]: Expense Account (Cost) -> Amount: +1,000.00 EUR (Tax Code V1 - 22%)

Credit [H]: Expense/Clearing Account (Rebate/Credit) -> Amount: -1,000.00 EUR (Tax Code V1 - 22%)

Debit [S]: Input VAT -> Amount: +220.00 EUR

Credit [H]: Input VAT (Correction) -> Amount: -220.00 EUR

Credit [H]: Vendor / Supplier Account -> Balance: 0.00 EUR

The system correctly calculates the taxes on the line items, and the mathematical sum of the document is zero. However, we are currently blocked by message M8 140 ("Invoiced amount must be greater than zero").

We need this restriction lifted to process these standard accounting settlements.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: Homogeneous Update and Copy to SAP Cloud using RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench
entry.content:
Introduction

In today‚Äôs rapidly evolving SAP landscape, customers are increasingly looking for seamless ways to upgrade and migrate their systems to leverage the full potential of SAP S/4HANA and the cloud. As part of the Early Adopter Program, I had the opportunity to work hands-on with the Transition Workbench tool to perform an upgrade from SAP S/4HANA 1909 to SAP S/4HANA 2023 FP03 and subsequently execute a migration to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP).

In this blog, I share my real-world experience from this project ‚Äî detailing the Update and Tenant Copy methods in SAP BTP Cloud Cockpit, how the Transition Workbench helped streamline the process, and the step-by-step approach I followed to carry out the upgrade and migration successfully. This write-up is designed to help consultants and customers alike understand the practical aspects, challenges, and best practices of such transformations.

I would like to take a moment to recognize and sincerely appreciate the efforts and valuable technical advisory of Ravikiran Chikati, Barathwaj, Arvind, Srivastava, Piyush and Klumpp, Fabian.  

Overview: Update and Copy to SAP Cloud Cockpit

This process describes how an on-premises SAP S/4HANA or SAP Business Suite (SOH) system is upgraded and replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition environment using the Transition Workbench and the Update & Copy to Cloud Cockpit approach.

The workflow begins with provisioning a skeleton target system and a migration server in the SAP Cloud environment (steps 1 & 2). The Transition Workbench acts as an intermediate layer to streamline preparation, replication, and upgrade tasks (steps 3‚Äì5).

On the source side, preparation steps are executed, the SUM tool performs the in-place upgrade, and the download directories are copied between the migration server and the source system (steps 4, 6, 7 & 8).

After ramp-down activities (step 9), the upgrade is completed, and the system is switched back to the main instance (steps 10 & 12). Finally, ECS post-processing ensures that the migrated and upgraded system is ready for productive use (step 13).

This phased approach‚Äîcovering Pre-Requisite Checks, Software Download, Preparation, Replication, Downtime Finalization, and Post-Processing‚Äîhelps customers move from an on-premises S/4HANA or SOH system to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP) efficiently and with minimal risk.

 

Introduction

In today‚Äôs rapidly evolving SAP landscape, customers are increasingly looking for seamless ways to upgrade and migrate their systems to leverage the full potential of SAP S/4HANA and the cloud. As part of the Early Adopter Program, I had the opportunity to work hands-on with the Transition Workbench tool to perform an upgrade from SAP S/4HANA 1909 to SAP S/4HANA 2023 FP03 and subsequently execute a migration to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP).

In this blog, I share my real-world experience from this project ‚Äî detailing the Update and Tenant Copy methods in SAP BTP Cloud Cockpit, how the Transition Workbench helped streamline the process, and the step-by-step approach I followed to carry out the upgrade and migration successfully. This write-up is designed to help consultants and customers alike understand the practical aspects, challenges, and best practices of such transformations.

I would like to take a moment to recognize and sincerely appreciate the efforts and valuable technical advisory of Ravikiran Chikati, Barathwaj, Arvind, Srivastava, Piyush and Klumpp, Fabian.  

Overview: Update and Copy to SAP Cloud Cockpit

This process describes how an on-premises SAP S/4HANA or SAP Business Suite (SOH) system is upgraded and replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition environment using the Transition Workbench and the Update & Copy to Cloud Cockpit approach.

The workflow begins with provisioning a skeleton target system and a migration server in the SAP Cloud environment (steps 1 & 2). The Transition Workbench acts as an intermediate layer to streamline preparation, replication, and upgrade tasks (steps 3‚Äì5).

On the source side, preparation steps are executed, the SUM tool performs the in-place upgrade, and the download directories are copied between the migration server and the source system (steps 4, 6, 7 & 8).

After ramp-down activities (step 9), the upgrade is completed, and the system is switched back to the main instance (steps 10 & 12). Finally, ECS post-processing ensures that the migrated and upgraded system is ready for productive use (step 13).

This phased approach‚Äîcovering Pre-Requisite Checks, Software Download, Preparation, Replication, Downtime Finalization, and Post-Processing‚Äîhelps customers move from an on-premises S/4HANA or SOH system to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP) efficiently and with minimal risk.

 

Pre-requisite

Provision/Validation of DNS names in RISE environment

Preparatory actions to be performed by ECS

  1. Provision the Migration VM and the Target System

You will receive the Migration VM details together with the handover of the target landscape details.‚Äã

Cockpit-Independent Preparatory Actions

Preparation activities required both from ECS and users to access and work with the "system transition workbench"

  • Preparatory actions to be performed by ECS

The "RISE with SAP system transition workbench" ("system transition workbench") is installed by ECS on a so-called Migration VM. After preparing the Migration VM, ECS hands it over to the migration partner.

Early Adopter program, are not provided by default on the Migration VM

  • Preparatory actions to be performed by Users
    • The workbench requires access to internet, preconfigured by the user's proxy.
    • Remote Function Call (RFC)
    • RFC requests are used for the communication to the application servers.
  • Migration VM must have connection to the source system to make RFC calls. the following source system parameters are required:
  • DDIC user in client 000 of the source system
  • Instance host
  • Domain
  • Instance number
  • Access to Services and Tools
    • The "system transition workbench" needs to access to the following:
    • The source system and the target SAP HANA database using SQL
    • The Maintenance Planner
    • The analytics service
    • The Software Download Service (SDS)
 

General Network Requirements

The "system transition workbench" has the following network requirements on the Migration VM:

  • Connection to source and target database using SQL ports
  • Connection to the source application server using remote function call (RFC)
  • Connection to the Maintenance Planner, SAP download services, CRLbag service, and analytics tools

Requirement for Maintenance Planner and HANA Replication

  • The source system must be known to the Maintenance Planner
  • Users must manually create a transaction in the Maintenance Planner
  • Validate all HANA Replication related parameters are applied on source and target database (Refer Pre-req sheet)
  • Validate if Log mode of Source to be Normal and keep monitoring log volume size to store logs to be replicated.
  • Validate if
  1. a) Auto failover should be disabled.
  2. b) Disable Database Hooks: Hooks are HA/DR providers which sends information to initiate auto failover. These can be disabled from global.ini file.
  • Validate if nameserver Service ports needs to be opened in Source System and target system, Range: 3<inst_id><service port> or 3<inst_id>XX. Telnet test can be performed to validated if ports are open

 

 

Created the ticket to enable the Migration VM from ECS. You will receive the mail after enabling the Migration VM from ECS. TWB tool has been installed on the migration server. Make sure you are on the latest Version before starting the project 

RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench Version: 0.36.1

 

 SAP System Transition Workbench
Once Enabled the Transition Workbench login to VDI or Citrix of customer access the Below URL

Note: LT1 Migration VM is meant for customer it can be accessed from the Customer Network only

https://<hostname>. <domain_name>:1129/lmsl/slocon/docs/index.html 

Login with user sapadm, if password not available reset at the OS level to get the password.

Create the Vault to secure the password storage, a KeePass Vault is to be created.       It will be encrypted with the vault password you enter.

 

Start the Uptime Phase

Uptime Phase has 3 Steps

  1. Pre-requisite Checks
  2. Download
  3. Preparation and Replication
 

Pre-requisites Checks

Start the Task 1.1: Pre-requisite Checks for Homogenous Conversion to SAP S/4 HANA

Below are the Parameter which needed for Tenant Copy

Source System

 

Target System

Confirm the setting can be applied to the target database of the productive system

Clear the result with error

Perform the backup of the Source and Target Database within the last 24 hours

Uninstall the LCAPPS and AFL components from the source database as it is not installed on the Target Database

Apply the SAP Note 3409764 in the Source System

Confirm the SAP Note has been applied on the Source System and proceed further

Software Download

Start the Task 2.1: Software Download

Preparation and Replication

Start the Task 3.1: Pre-requisite for Homogeneous Conversion to SAP S/4 HANA

 





Start the Task 3.2: Initialize and Monitor SAP HANA Replication

 

Execute the below SQL Statement to check the Replication Status

SELECT DATABASE_NAME, SOURCE_HOST, TARGET_HOST, REPLICATION_STATUS, REPLICATION_STATUS_DETAILS, LAST_LOG_POSITION, LAST_LOG_POSITION_TIME, SHIPPED_LOG_POSITION, SHIPPED_LOG_POSITION_TIME from SYS_DATABASES.M_DATABASE_REPLICA_STATISTICS

Once Replication Status in ACTIVE Status

Copy the Downloaded Directory from LT1 (Migration VM) to Source System

Copy the addons into this Download Directory

Start the SUM on the Source System

SUM Uptime Activities

cd /usr/sap/CS5/Cycle2/SUM/abap/

./SUMSTART confighostagent SID

 

SUM URL - https://<hostname>.<domainname>:1129/lmsl/sumabap/SID/slui

Extraction

 
Configuration Phase

 

Checks Phase

 

Prep-processing Phase

 

Ramp-down Activities Before downtime

Execution Phase

 

Post Processing After Downtime

 

Finalize Replication Steps

 

Start the Downtime Phase in this phase you have two steps

  1. Finalize
  2. Post-Processing

 

Start the Task 1.1: Finalize Tenant Replication for Homogeneous Conversion to SAP HANA

 

Start the Task 2.1: Post-Processing

 

Confirm and proceed further to complete the Transition workbench

Perform the Post Activities

Execute the Report SHDB_MIGRATION_CHECK

 

Manual Post Processing

 

Create the SR Ticket to Switch Application back to Main instance after the Migration

Update hdbuserstore and Check R3trans -d / -x (Validate connection to DB is working on all APPS)

Updated as part of the Switch Main Instance SR

 

Perform the Post Activities

Silent Data Migration

Go to transaction SDM_MON -> Current Client Info

Run SJOBREPO -> SAP_SDM_EXECUTOR_POSTPROCESSING

Handover to ECS Post Processing

entry.title: Issue Verifiable Credentials for the Swiss E-ID environment on the SAP Business Technology Platform
entry.content:
Setting Up the swiyu Generic Issuer on SAP BTP

Having your ID, drivers license, professional certification, insurance confirmation all on your phone can make your life easier. With the Swiss E-ID infrastructure, that‚Äôs possible. Both government bodies and non-government organizations (reads: companies or yourself) can use the trust infrastructure of the Swiss E-ID to issue their own certificates.

Building on our first blog post on verifying the Swiss E-ID, this article now explores the next step: how to issue your own digital credentials using the swiyu Generic Issuer. If you haven‚Äôt read the verification blog yet, we recommend starting there for background on the architecture and trust model.

In this post, we walk through how to deploy the swiyu Generic Issuer ‚Äì the official reference implementation for issuing verifiable credentials ‚Äì on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). This allows your business applications to create and deliver swiyu-compatible credentials (such as identity proofs, age confirmations, or membership cards) directly into users‚Äô wallets. The result: a streamlined, secure, and privacy-preserving alternative to traditional ID checks or manual credentialing workflows.

Business Relevance

Many business processes require issuing credentials. For example, companies issuing digital certificates to new employees (like an employee ID), to customers (membership cards or warranties), credentials of certifications, or to minors (age-restriction certificates). This involved validating pictures of paper documents with tedious validation steps. With swiyu‚Äôs infrastructure, the Generic Issuer can create signed digital credentials that go straight into a user‚Äôs swiyu wallet; these credentials are cryptographically signed, ensuring they are tamper-proof and digitally verifiable by anyone, and crucially, empower the certificate holder to selectively decide exactly which information they share with the verifier. This streamlines workflows like HR onboarding, verification of certificates, KYC (know your customer, the identification of legal or natural persons in the financial industry), or age checks: issuing is done via trusted digital channels without disclosing extra data, since the user‚Äôs identity attributes never leave their device

Architecture

The swiyu Generic Issuer is a government-provided reference implementation bundling all the core functionality needed for credential issuance. It runs as your own server (for example on SAP BTP) with a backing database, and it interacts with the swiyu trust infrastructure. The issuer service uses a Decentralized Identifier (DID) registered in the swiyu Base Registry (holding its public keys) and is listed in the Trust Registry (for trust statements). When issuing a credential, the issuer talks to a user‚Äôs swiyu wallet via standard APIs, and to the swiyu Trust Registry to publish status updates (e.g. revocation). The holder‚Äôs wallet only releases attributes to the issuer with user consent. The overall system is illustrated below:

Figure 1: Basic architecture of the swiyu-issuer implementation on SAP BTP

 

Setting Up Your Own Issuer on SAP BTP

Prerequisites:

  • Cloud foundry space
  • PostgreSQL Entitlement
  • Registered application / business on the FOITTs platform (for details see here)

Now deploy the Generic Issuer service on SAP BTP:

  1. Provision Database: In the SAP BTP Cockpit (or CF CLI), create a PostgreSQL service instance in your space. Once provisioned, generate a service key to retrieve credentials (host, port, username, password) for your application.
  2. Prepare Environment Variables: On your local machine, create a manifest.yml for Cloud Foundry push and a .env file (or use cf set-env) defining the needed variables. (E.g. ISSUER_ID, EXTERNAL_URL, SWIYU_PARTNER_ID, etc.)
    1. Be aware that you specify the fields of your to-issue credential in the ‚Äúissuer-metadata‚Äù.
  3. Status Registry Credentials: the SWIYU_STATUS_REGISTRY_* keys, tokens and URLs obtained from the API portal (customer key/secret, refresh token, OAuth token URL, status API URL).
  4. Verification Methods: the DID‚Äôs verification method identifiers for status and SD-JWT signing (from the DID log). For example, DID_STATUS_LIST_VERIFICATION_METHOD must match the DID assertion key used for the status list.
  1. Deploy the Issuer App: Set the Docker image for swiyu-issuer. (FOITT provides ready images on Docker Hub.) Use cf push with your manifest to deploy the issuer. After pushing, the issuer‚Äôs management API and Swagger UI will be available.
  2. Initialize Status List: Before issuing any credential, the issuer must initialize a status list slot. Call the issuer‚Äôs management API endpoint  ‚Äì save this URL and ID for use when issuing credentials. This step creates the on-chain slot needed to track revocations.
  3. Access and Secure the API: You can explore the issuer‚Äôs endpoints using its built-in Swagger UI (e.g. at https://<your-app>/swagger-ui.html). All calls for creating offers and checking status can be tested here. For any management or production deployment, secure the API (e.g. via a fixed asymmetric key or OAuth2) to prevent unauthorized issuance. (Note: The default configuration is for experimentation; for production-grade security consult FOITT‚Äôs deployment guide.)
  4. Optional: Frontend Integration: For user convenience, you may build a simple front-end (e.g. a SAP UI5 or CAP service) that interacts with the issuer API. In a PoC we integrated JWT-based authentication with a UI5 app so end-users can easily trigger and view issuance. This is not strictly required, but can streamline the UX when customers interact with the issuance flow.

Issuing Credentials

With the issuer running and initialized, you can now issue credentials. The general flow is:

  • Your application triggers a credential offer: call the issuer‚Äôs POST /management/api/credentials endpoint with the credential data. This includes fields like credential_subject_data (e.g. name, birthdate) and the "status_lists" array containing the statusRegistryUrl from before.
  • The response will contain a management_id and an offer_deeplink URL. The latter is a QR-code deep link for the swiyu wallet. Render this (e.g. as a QR code in your web page). When the wallet scans it, the holder sees an issuance request (prompt to accept or decline).
  • Revocation/Suspension: Later, if needed (e.g. a credential should be cancelled or suspended), update its status via PATCH with credentialStatus=REVOKED or SUSPENDED. This updates the public status list so verifiers know the credential is no longer valid.

To illustrate: after issuing an offer, the terminal shows something like

{"management_id":"abc123", "offer_deeplink":"swiyu-issue://?client_id=..."}

You turn that deep link into a QR code and scan it with the swiyu wallet. The wallet then prompts the user to accept the new credential. Once accepted, the issuer marks it as ISSUED in the registry. The user‚Äôs device now holds a signed verifiable credential (e.g. their new digital e-ID).

Figure 2: Credential offer on the users swiyu-wallet

 

 

Conclusion

By following these steps, you will have your own swiyu Generic Issuer running on SAP BTP, registered as a valid issuer in the Swiss trust registry, and ready to issue QR-based e-ID credentials. In practice, this lets you integrate trusted digital credential issuance into any business process ‚Äì from HR identity checks, to age verification in e‚Äëcommerce, to verification of certifications, to KYC/AML flows ‚Äì without costly manual ID or document scans. All credential data remains cryptographically protected and on the user‚Äôs device, while your service simply asks the swiyu trust infrastructure to verify the issuer‚Äôs identity and handle revocations.

Next Steps: Be sure to, if you haven‚Äôt yet, check out our blog post on setting up and deploying the swiyu Generic Verifier on SAP BTP. Together, these components complete the swiyu ecosystem on SAP BTP, enabling fully digital, privacy-preserving identity and credential workflows.

entry.title: From Vision to Reality: Our 2025 Milestones in AI, Cloud, and Industry Transformation
entry.content:
As I reflect on 2025, I am proud of what our team accomplished by aligning with the broader priorities shaping SAP and our industry. We adopted an AI-first approach, accelerated the adoption of S/4HANA, and made a significant shift towards cloud- and data-driven business models. This year, we transitioned from strategy to execution by embedding AI and automation into our core processes, modernizing our infrastructure with hybrid and private cloud strategies, and unifying our data on platforms like SAP BTP and the Business Data Cloud.

  • Field logistics & Joule: We launched the ‚ÄúWhere is my stuff‚Äù Joule use case in Q3. Bringing mobility and AI into a customer-facing scenario delivered real field visibility improvements‚Äîand the engagement we saw at ASUG events, plus our new AWS partnership, validated the demand for practical, production-ready AI agents. Our active participation in ACOGE workstreams for Finance‚ÄëJVA and Field Logistics helped shape roadmaps that matter to customers.
  • Upstream Hydrocarbon Accounting & Management (UHAM): We made tangible progress to help customers adopt clean‚Äëcore and fit‚Äëto‚Äëstandard approaches. Deliverables in 2025 included new APIs and CDS views, additional compliance reports, and features that accelerate S/4HANA migration‚Äîspecifically, Legacy PPA/PPN handling and PRA integration with Treasury to enable ongoing payment processing. We also introduced UHAM BDC data products for well completions, volumes, and accounting-document data. Early AI work, such as Zero‚ÄëTouch Data Entry, is being developed to capture key data from plant statements and reduce manual effort.
  • Downstream & Retail (SDM and RFNO): SDM moved closer to an industry-agnostic offering, with better forecasting, automatic trip creation, and smarter automation that will broaden its market fit starting in 2026. RFNO made strong strides toward replacing legacy SSR‚Äîimproving service‚Äëstation network, settlement and aggregation processes, and AI-driven pricing logic that supports autonomous learning and automated price population at the pump.
  • sto360 (STO excellence): sto360 shifted from a powerful point tool to a strategic, SAP-aligned STO platform. This year‚Äôs enhancements‚Äîturnaround planning workspaces, automated scope definition, risk-based prioritization, contractor orchestration, digital QA/QC, and SAP BTP analytics‚Äîare already delivering better schedule reliability, cost control, and execution visibility for customers across Oil & Gas, Utilities, Chemicals, and Mining.

What this means going into 2026: the cleaner core integrations, open APIs, stronger partner ecosystem, and practical AI deployments we delivered in 2025 set the stage for deeper S/4HANA alignment, expanded Joule use cases, broader SDM availability, RFNO readiness for marketplace needs, and continued sto360 innovation.

In-person industry events:
I‚Äôm grateful we connected in 2025 at

  • SBN Energy Day ‚Äî 26 March, Stavanger (Equinor), Norway
  • Baker Hughes Annual Meeting ‚Äî 2‚Äì4 Feb, Florence, Italy
  • SAP for Energy and Utilities Conference ‚Äî 8‚Äì10 April, Rotterdam, Netherlands
  • SAPPHIRE Orlando ‚Äî 19‚Äì21 May, Orlando, Florida, USA
  • SAPPHIRE Madrid ‚Äî 26‚Äì28 May, Madrid, Spain
  • Reuters Events: Data Driven Oil & Gas ‚Äî 24‚Äì25 June, Houston, Texas, USA
  • OKC Innovation Day ‚Äî 23 July
  • Total Plant Maintenance ‚Äî 9‚Äì11 Sept, Dubai, UAE
  • ASUG Best Practices ‚Äî 6‚Äì8 Oct, Houston, Texas, USA
  • SAP for Asset and Service Management Conference ‚Äî 8‚Äì9 Oct, Rome, Italy
  • NA Energy Capital Assembly ‚Äî 22‚Äì23 Oct, Houston, Texas, USA

Thank you to every customer, partner, and SAP colleague who brought energy, feedback, and partnership to these efforts‚Äîyour collaboration made this year‚Äôs outcomes possible.

Wishing you and your loved ones a joyful holiday season and a peaceful, prosperous Christmas!

entry.title: Healthcare integration - Patient as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private
entry.content:
In this blog, I'll give a sneak preview on various integration possibilities between Hospital Information Systems and an ERP system. I'll go into details about an integration package which creates patient as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private. In the healthcare context, integration of patient data is important with most of the business process inside a hospital revolves around the patient. Before I go into details of the integration package, let‚Äôs first understand a few key words and use case.

Key words

SAP Cloud ERP Private refers to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

SAP BTP refers to SAP Business Technology Platform.

Integration Packages are a set of preconfigured integration artifacts for specific business process between various systems involved. 

Business Partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private is a central master data object that represents an organization, person, or group of people showing a business relationship.

FHIR refers to Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources. FHIR¬Æ is the registered trademarks of Health Level Seven International.

Perspective

There are many use cases where hospital data is available in an EMR (Electronic Medical Record) system like treatment, staffs and care-givers, billing and claims and so on. This data needs to be exchanged with SAP Cloud ERP Private to do business processes.

We need data exchange to improve agility and clarity for effective decision-making and to adapt for business transformation correctly.

Patient as a business partner is just one of the integration use cases. The integration package which I talk about in this blog offers template and guidance to integrate more such data. Entities like departments, vendors, personnel (Doctors and Hospital staffs), insurance, and so on, are some examples of data needed for integration. Such data integration will help in realizing business processes for finance, supply chain, workforce management and so on.

SAP Health Data Services for FHIR supports all the FHIR resources and serves as a domain model for data integration between EMR and SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Use Case

Why we need to represent the patient as a business partner? Let‚Äôs consider billing as an example at the hospital, where a patient could be a self-payer or a co-payer. We need to do Account Receivable management in SAP Cloud ERP Private for payment tracking and collection.  

Hence, the patient needs to be kept as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Onboarding - SAP Health Data Services for FHIR

For integration to be established, you need to have a key BTP service which is SAP Health Data Services for FHIR. For details, refer to the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/f64d5f2b858042f791b64bdd4094df22/872ceb743a38498bb960b916de6cde5d.html

This onboarding steps are made simple using the BTP booster which automates all the onboarding steps for you, and you can refer to the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/4613ca2972b540168ab4e03bf72023d7/de0e3033cda5477691db3bd521bbb163.html

Another step is to configure the patient resource in SAP Health Data Services for FHIR by profiling the patient resource. Refer the following link:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/f754dd80490a41c996927fac6116feba.html

Setting up access control in cloud connector

We need this step to establish secure communication between SAP BTP and SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Use the following link to complete the setup of access control in the cloud connector.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/de25990e3bfb40c29cdc2a6df49fd63e.html

Finding an Integration Package

  • Go to https://api.sap.com/ and select ‚ÄúIntegration‚Äù.

 

  • Then in the following tabbed options select ‚ÄúDiscover Integrations‚Äù and enter ‚ÄúSAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition‚Äù in the ‚ÄúFind‚Äù to search.

 

  • Enter ‚ÄúSAP Health Data Services for FHIR‚Äù as a product to integrate. You'll get the integration package as shown after this.

 

  • Select the package to view its content. You'll see that it includes one Integration Flow ‚ÄúReplicate Patients from SAP Health Data Services for FHIR to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition‚Äù.

Importing Integration Package

There are two ways in which an integration package can be imported and executed.

  • Using the configured workspace of the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Steps are described here:

https://help.sap.com/docs/business-accelerator-hub/sap-business-accelerator-hub/consume-content?version=Cloud

  • Copying the integration content in the SAP Cloud Integration Suite (Recommended)

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/38a01529209a4dc999ded3b9dd05a552.html

  • Once imported into the Integration Suite, you can see the package in the ‚ÄúDesign‚Äù tab.

Configurations

  • Setting up cloud connector in SAP BTP for secure communication with SAP Cloud ERP Private.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/de25990e3bfb40c29cdc2a6df49fd63e.html

  • Maintain the message queue
    • Make sure you have the proper role collection assigned to your user in BTP. Refer the link: https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/799852ea657e400fa07700e976285b14.html
    • Navigate to the BTP dashboard to locate an Event Mesh service instance bound to SAP Health Data Services for FHIR instance.
    • Go to the Event Mesh application.

    • Click on the proper ‚ÄúMessage Client‚Äù in the Event Mesh dashboard. Client here refers to the Event Mesh service instance which you've created along with SAP Health Data Services for FHIR provisioning.

    • Click on the tab ‚ÄúQueues‚Äù and then ‚ÄúCreate Queue‚Äù.

    • In the subsequent pop-up window, offer your own queue name and click on create. Don't enter values for any other fields. Next for the created queue, click on the ‚ÄúActions‚Äù column as highlighted in blue and select ‚ÄúQueue Subscriptions‚Äù.

    • In the subsequent pop-up window, offer the topic as ‚Äúcoredata/Patient‚Äù, click on Add and then close the window.

    • This completes the Event Mesh configuration.
  • Security Material in Integration Suite.
    • Go to the Integration Suite subscription application in your sub-account.

  • Click on ‚ÄúMonitor‚Äù, next ‚ÄúIntegrations and APIs‚Äù and then ‚ÄúSecurity Materials‚Äù.

  • Maintain ‚ÄúSecurity Materials‚Äù for the three application and services involved in the integration like following. All the needed information can be retrieved from the service key of the respective services. For each Security Material after filling in the needed inputs, click on Deploy. Ensure that the grant type is as shown. Use the following link to get a detailed description about each field value and configuration.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/cd5f25e58497425d9f500f0abbd39363.html#procedure

  • Security Material for Event Mesh.

  • Security Material for SAP Health Data Services for FHIR.

  • Security Material for SAP Cloud ERP Private.

  • This completes the security credential configuration in SAP Integration Suite.

 

  • Configure integration package artifact.
    • Navigate to the iFlow inside the copied integration package.

  • Click on the ‚ÄúArtifacts‚Äù tab, select the iFlow and click on Configure.

  • In the next pop-up window, enter the following details for the ‚ÄúSender‚Äù, ‚ÄúReceiver‚Äù and ‚ÄúMore‚Äù tab.
  • Use the following link to get a detailed description about each field value and configuration.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HEALTH_DATA_SERVICES_FOR_FHIR/88d3c4c1e7bd416cb4f23907e0a4641d/c1e3e07667f6463f9b68f0bd446e1c02.html

  • Enter the following details in the ‚ÄúReceiver‚Äù tab.

  • Enter the following details in the ‚ÄúMore‚Äù tab.

  • Click ‚ÄúDeploy All‚Äù to deploy the configuration.

Monitoring

After the above configuration deployment, integration flow status changes to ‚ÄúStarted‚Äù and can be monitored. Use the following link to monitor the integration.

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/monitor-integrations

When patient is created in SAP Health Data Services for FHIR, based on the preceding steps, the integration flow will automatically create the corresponding business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private.

Conclusion

With this, I'll like to summarize the blog.

Blog offers you a step-by-step guide to realize integration for the patient data as a business partner in SAP Cloud ERP Private. Share your experience about the integration package, application, and services used during integration. Are you familiar with the FHIR standard and the resources? If yes, then how do you use within your hospital landscape and for interoperability between systems.

Do let us know through the comments. I'll love to hear your reactions and feedback through comments.

entry.title: Re: Issue with Budget Display in "Monitor Project" App ‚Äì...
entry.content: I‚Äôve run into the same budget display issue in the Monitor Project app on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. In many cases, it‚Äôs caused by missing or incomplete configuration in project control settings or budgeting not being released properly. Make sure the project has an active financial plan and that the relevant WBS elements are assigned correctly. Also check whether the budget profile is activated and if the authorization roles allow budget viewing. A data refresh or cache clear sometimes helps as well. If everything looks right, submitting an SAP support ticket usually gets the issue resolved quickly.

entry.title: Streamlining Expat Air Ticket Allowances: How SAP Ticket Benefit Solution Meets MENA Workforce Needs
entry.content:
In the MENA region, expatriate employees are often entitled to receive air tickets for themselves and their dependents to travel back to their home countries. For HR and payroll teams, managing these entitlements accurately while staying compliant with local regulations and company policy can be complex. SAP Ticket Benefit solution offers a streamlined and flexible approach to address this challenge.

Overview of SAP Ticket Benefit Solution

The Ticket Benefit solution enables companies to manage ticket entitlements for expat employees and their dependents, whether provided as a monetary allowance or an actual ticket. It supports:

  • Flexible setup aligned with company policy
  • Annual, semi-annual, or custom frequencies
  • Configurable rules for dependents, travel routes, and ticket classes

High-Level Process Steps

Key Features

The solution is built on four core components:

  • Entitlement Recording - Infotype 3408
    The process begins by recording each employee‚Äôs entitlement details, such as: 
    • Accrual vs. in-full ticket
    • Frequency of ticket issuance
    • Number of tickets per cycle
    • Travel route and ticket class
    • Number of dependents covered

           These configurations allow organizations to accurately reflect their policies within the system.

  • Calculation - Payroll Function TBCAL
    During payroll runs, the function calculates the ticket balance for each employee and their dependents based on the Infotype records and the Ticket Benefit customizing settings. 

           This ensures entitlement values are updated and reflected in payroll results.

  • Ticket Compensation:
    • Issuing Ticket - Infotype 3409
      For companies that provide actual travel tickets instead of cash allowances, admins can record each ticket issuance directly in Infotype 3409 to keep the system aligned with the tickets provided.
    • Ticket Auto Encashment ‚Äì Workbench
      The new Ticket Benefit Workbench further streamlines ticket allowance processing by identifying employees and dependents who have reached the end of their ticket cycle. It enables bulk creation of compensation records, reducing manual effort while improving process consistency and transparency. For implementation details, please refer to SAP Note 3680164.
  • Correction - Infotype 3410
    When adjustments are required, Infotype 3410 allows admins to specify who the correction applies to and add or deduct the appropriate number of tickets. This ensures ticket balances remain accurate and up to date.

Conclusion

The SAP Ticket Benefit solution is more than a compliance enabler. By leveraging this solution, organizations can:

  • Improve operational efficiency through automation and bulk processing
  • Maintain accurate entitlement records
  • Enhance employee satisfaction

For detailed documentation and configuration guidance, refer to the SAP Help Portal.

entry.title: Considerations when implementing IAS for SuccessFactors Onboarding
entry.content:
In H2 2026 the username and password authentication process for onboarding will be deprecated and they will need to use IAS to log in.  In this article we will discuss various options to consider when implementing IAS for onboarding.  We will assume that IAS is already enabled for Employee Central.

Implementing IAS is quite simple for an onboarding perspective, a switch is enabled in provisioning and emails need to be adjusted.  All the logic in IAS should be built by an IAS consultant.

Emails

When IAS is enabled for onboarding the ‚Äòusername/password‚Äô is sent from IAS rather than from SuccessFactors.  I prefer to still send the ‚ÄòExternal Welcome email‚Äô from SuccessFactors Onboarding.  The welcome email explains that they will get a second email with the login credentials.  I prefer to send two emails as we can customize this email to a greater extent than the IAS email.  In the welcome email you will need to remove the password reset and username, and this will need to be removed for the rehire email as well.  The login link in the other emails will work with IAS.

To get two emails to be sent at the same time will require the real time synch in IAS.

The first email comes from SuccessFactors Onboarding.  This is the external email welcome template. 

The second email comes at the same time from IAS and will allow them to set their password to log in.

To log on they click on the link, and they set their password.

Once they have reset their password they should be redirect to the login page; to do this you will need to set up the redirect in IAS.

Once they have submitted their username and password you can choose to add a new layer of authentication.  Once way is to send a code to their email address.  You can also send this by SMS but this will require a third party provider.

Once they submit the code they will be able to log in.

Once they log in, they can proceed with onboarding as normal.

On their hire date the individual will not get a new IAS account but will be moved to an employee group and they will be able to log in with same IAS account. 

Rehires

When an employee is terminated from Employee Central then their details are typically deleted from IAS, they can be made inactivated, but it is advised that they are deleted.  ips.delete.existedbefore.entities=true

When onboarding starts the onboardee receives an email as above.  When the rehire, check has been completed it follows the same process as without IAS, they get an new IAS email to go in that is linked to their inactive Employee Central Account.  As the old IAS account was deleted this is new IAS account but liked to the inactive user record.  Once they log in their can proceed with onboarding as normal.

When deploying IAS, it is imperative that the rehire process is fully tested.

Implementing IAS whilst live with Onboarding.

Some onboardees  will be using the old username and password method.  As you approach the deployment, we suggest the following.

  • About 2-3 weeks before go live update the welcome email so users know you are changing the authentication process, and they will get a new email to log in. 
  • Add this to a custom homepage tile, this is just there to prevent any concerns over phishing.
  • On go live day pause all initiation of onboarding
  • Update onboarding IAS email with text applicable to all onboardee who are currently in the process, explaining what they need to do.
  • Synch onboarding with IAS, once this is completed update onboarding IAS email with standard text
  • Restart onboarding initiation

entry.title: Re: Inclusion of field Requisitioner in Production Operat...
entry.content:
Hello @KeLaw 

Thank you for your question.

Below are some insightful links to support you:

Implementing a Business Add-in (BAdI): Check a Purchase Requisition, App Extensibility: My Purchase Requisitions, KBA 2955651

The simple answer to your question is NO, not in a supported way. Let me explain.

In summary, the public cloud due to its modular approach does not support adding the Requisitioner (AFNAM) field to the External Processing tab of an operation‚Äôs production-order because is a GUI application. Also, you cannot extend the GUI screen with key-user tools.

The choice of making AFNAM mandatory in your system will therefore block purchase requisitions that your system created automatically from external-processing operation because users have no place to maintain that field beforehand.

Instead of changing the PP operations UI, my suggestion is for you to use BAdI MM_PUR_S4_MODIFY_ITEM in the Custom Logic app to enable you derive and populate AFNAM automatically for your PR items which originate from production orders and then keep your existing check in MM_PUR_S4_PR_CHECK. This will ensure every purchase requisition has a valid requisitioner and you will also be sticking with the clean-core approach.

You may consider building a logic. below is a quick guide.

In your Custom Logic App, create a new enhancement implementation

Select as described in the screen (Business Context: Procurement: Purchase Requisition Item, BAdI: MM_PUR_S4_PR_MODIFY_ITEM). You can add logic that detects PR item,

derive a suitable requisitioner such as MRP Controller, set PurchaseRequisitionItem-Requistioner accordingly when it is initial.

You can keep your existing logic but only raise an error if AFNAM is still not initial after the system has run the modify BAdI.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP CPI Best Practices for Designing High-Performance iFlows
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community!

  This is officially my first-ever blog, and I‚Äôm super excited (and slightly nervous) to share my learning with all of you. If you find this useful, please like, comment, or drop any suggestions that can help me improve. I truly appreciate your feedback!

Now, let‚Äôs get into the fun part:

‚Äú SAP CPI Best Practices for Designing High-Performance iFlows.‚Äù

If you've ever created an iFlow that started simple but ended up looking like a bowl of spaghetti, trust me, I have been there too. CPI works best when we treat it gently, keep things clean, and avoid lifting heavy weights unnecessarily.

So here‚Äôs a friendly, simple, real-world explanation of how you can build faster, smarter, happier iFlows this year.

1. Keep Your iFlow Simple

Complex iFlow = Slow Performance

  Avoid unnecessary branches, loops, or overly stuffed mappings.

Visual Example:

BAD DESIGN (Spaghetti iFlow)

‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ[Start]

‚îÇ

‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄIf

‚îÇ     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄIf

‚îÇ         ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄIf

‚îÇ             ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄGroovy Script (200 lines)

‚îÇ                 ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄMapping

‚îÇ                     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄAnother Mapping

‚îÇ

‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ[End]

GOOD DESIGN (Clean iFlow)

‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ[Start]

‚îÇ

‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄRouter ‚Üí Mapping ‚Üí Script (If needed)

‚îÇ

‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ[End]

Real Example:

 A client had 10 content modifiers. After cleaning up unused ones and merging logic, the iFlow went from 24 seconds ‚Üí 4 seconds.

2. Use Parallel Processing When Possible

If your work doesn‚Äôt depend on sequence, divide it!

Mini Diagram

               ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ Branch A

[Input] ‚Üí Fork ‚îÄ‚î§

                ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ Branch B

It‚Äôs like carrying groceries: why carry one tomato at a time when you have two hands?

Real Example:

Processing 500 employee records in parallel batches reduced execution time by 70%.

3. Reduce Message Size ‚Äî CPI Is Not a Weightlifter

Large payloads slow down your CPI tenant.

 Don‚Äôt send the entire data package when you only need a few fields.

Funny Analogy:

  Like ordering a truck to deliver a packet of noodles.

 Your neighbors will judge you. CPI will too.

Real Example:

  A 12MB XML file was reduced to 3MB after removing unused segments, resulting in a significantly faster iFlow.

4. Use Groovy Scripts Wisely

Groovy is powerful‚Ä¶ but don‚Äôt use it for everything.

 If a graphical mapping works, use it.

Groovy Logic Flow

Good Use Cases:

‚úîÔ∏èDynamic Header Setting

‚úîÔ∏èCustom Transformations

‚úîÔ∏èString Manipulation

Avoid:

‚úñÔ∏è400-line mega scripts

‚úñÔ∏èFull-blown mappings that CPI mapping can handle

Real Example:

  A huge mapping Groovy script was replaced with a graphical map ‚Üí 60% performance boost.

5. Cache Reusable Data

If your iFlow needs the same lookup value 100 times, don‚Äôt call the API 100 times.

Simple Diagram

Without Cache

iFlow ‚Üí API ‚Üí API ‚Üí API ‚Üí API ‚Üí ...

With Cache

iFlow ‚Üí API (Once) ‚Üí Store ‚Üí Reuse ‚Üí Reuse

Real Example:

  A currency service was called for each line item.

 After caching, API calls dropped by 99%, and the customer stopped calling me about performance issues.

6. Use the Right Adapter

Choose adapters based on your scenario needs.

Funny Analogy:

 Using a truck to deliver a biscuit technically works‚Ä¶

 But why‚Ä¶ just why?

Real Example:

 Switching from SOAP to HTTPS adapter reduced processing time by 1.5 seconds per call.

7. Monitor Everything

CPI gives hints when something is wrong ‚Äî in Message Monitoring, Logs, or Cloud ALM.

Funny Line:

 CPI is like a baby.

 It doesn‚Äôt stay quiet when something is wrong‚Ä¶

 It screams (in the logs).

Simple Monitoring Flow

Message Monitor ‚Üí Check Logs ‚Üí Identify Pattern ‚Üí Fix iFlow ‚Üí Re-test

Real Example:

Frequent Java heap space errors in logs revealed that large payloads were filling memory, and splitting messages fixed the issue immediately.

Final Thoughts

Designing high-performance iFlows in 2025 is all about being smart, simple, and intentional:

‚úîÔ∏èKeep your iFlows clean

 ‚úîÔ∏è Reduce unnecessary steps

 ‚úîÔ∏è Avoid heavy payloads

 ‚úîÔ∏è Use scripts wisely

 ‚úîÔ∏è Monitor often

 ‚úîÔ∏è And don‚Äôt make CPI do gym workouts, it didn‚Äôt sign up for 

Thank you for reading my first-ever SAP Community blog!

 I‚Äôm really excited to keep learning and sharing here.

If you enjoyed it or have suggestions, please like, drop a comment, or share your advice.

 Your feedback will help me grow!

Thank you

Dinesh

entry.title: Re: Cannot change Home Page for SAP Build Work Zone advan...
entry.content:
If anyone else stumbles in here, for answer to why you can't edit the start page as admin, after completing the booster, I fixed this problem by renaming the display name of the group the "Workzone Admin" in SCIM under "Users & Authorizations" --> "Groups", to "Workzone_Admin".

The reason for this mismatch, is that the configuration (after completing the booster), states that the group display name must be "Workzone_Admin" - with the underscore in between the words, while the configuration guide tells you to name the group "Workzone Admin" with a space between the words.

entry.title: CORS Policy in SAC with live connection to BW
entry.content:
Hello!

We have been running SAC dashboards from our CRM system via an URL that is inserted in the CRM system.

Last week we had a security update on our network and now this is not working anymore. No changes have been made in BW or SAC!

We have a live BW connection with SAML to our SAC system and we have no problems running stories directly in SAC, it is when we call the stories from our CRM system we get the problem.

We get to SAC but when SAC calls BW we get the following error:

Access to XMLHttpRequest at 'https://lspappbw01.itpap.local:44300/sap/bw/ina/GetServerInfo?sap-client=010' from origin 'https://papyrus-1.eu10.hcs.cloud.sap' has been blocked by CORS policy: Permission was denied for this request to access the `unknown` address space.

Running the same URL directly in edge works fine and also in SAC.

Can you advice what to do?

 

/Maria

entry.title: Your key to next-level liquidity: Working Capital Management with SAP Taulia
entry.content:
Liquidity is crucial in today‚Äôs economic climate. While interest rates are rising and refinancing becomes ever more challenging for companies all sizes, a lack of liquidity can heavily disrupt your entire supply chain. So, it‚Äôs time to start thinking about your working capital strategy and SAP Taulia is here to help.

Being one of the key components in SAP S/4HANA Cloud‚Äôs treasury portfolio, SAP Taulia helps you to bring your working capital strategy to life. The cashflow orchestration platform is tightly integrated into SAP ERP and SAP Business Network, has access to many funders, delivers AI and analytics capabilities, and supports your sustainability journey as well.

 Curious? Let‚Äôs dive into more detail, SAP Taulia consists of two scope items that can be activated independently in your SAP ERP: 7DX (Receivables Financing with SAP Taulia) and 7MG (Payables Financing with SAP Taulia).

Scope item 7DX unlocks receivables financing capabilities in your ERP system. Shortly said, this enables you to unlock cash trapped in your invoices remarkably improving your cash flow.

Scope item 7MG covers the Payables side of your business, offering Virtual Cards, Dynamic Discounting and Supply Chain Finance. Dynamic Discounting basically means that you get a discount from suppliers in exchange for early payments. Supply Chain Finance, works similar, but instead a funder makes the early payment and you repay them later.  Virtual Cards, support you in automating and making your transactions safer and easier.

As of release S/4HANA Public Cloud 2508 7MG: Payables Financing with Taulia is the successor of 4AV: Supplier Finance in S/4HANA. Customers who want to set up Supplier Financing will now need to activate scope item 7MG.

This is of course only the tip of the iceberg. If you want to learn more about SAP Taulia, its value add for your business, customer examples, demos and more, I can sincerely recommend to take a look at the below resources:

  • Free learning journey, for a comprehensive overview
  • Solution overview, for a high level overview of SAP Taulia
  • Technical documentation, for an overview of everything that is available
  • Product Tours, for a sneak peek how the products look in the system
  • Follow SAP Taulia on Linkedin to not miss any new updates

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Public Cloud - API Availability for BP Extens...
entry.content:
Dear @byd,

Question 1.

Answer: Yes

Standard API:

  • API name (business): Business Partner (A2X) OData API
  • Technical service name: API_BUSINESS_PARTNER
  • Protocol: OData V2
  • Communication scenario (S/4HANA Cloud, public edition):
    Business Partner, Customer and Supplier Integration (SAP_COM_0008)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/85043858ea0f9244e10000000a4450e5.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/f7399c7374d3475a96a56a0856b5f3ee.html

This API allows read, create, update, delete of Business Partner, Customer, and Supplier data

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/1e488b3c40ff4ed3a96be20d3850b26d.html

Extension custom fields:

Answer: Yes, custom BP fields can be read via this API, provided they are created and enabled correctly:

1. Create the custom field in business context
Master Data: Business Partner (BP_CUSTVEND1) using the Custom Fields app

 

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/339c235db4e6448ab01664008ee3036b.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/46632054fa9d49a18b452ee287173aba.html

2. On the UI tab enable usage for the Business Partner (A2X) service, then Publish.
The Business Partner (A2X) help explicitly states the API entities are extensible via Custom Fields

 

3. After publishing the custom field:

    • Appears in the OData service metadata.
    • Can be selected in $select and returned in read calls

So BP master data including extension fields is fully retrievable via API_BUSINESS_PARTNER as long as those fields are defined via Key User extensibility and enabled for the service.

Older IDoc-based options like DEBMAS/CREMAS exist but are explicitly not recommended for new integrations in current Public Cloud releases

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3c916ef10fc240c9afc594b346ffaf77/a04825050c1740ef98032dccb2b8d682.html

Question 2.
Answer: Yes, but via the generic Journal Entry change SOAP API, not an AR-specific OData service.

On the FI open item journal entry line side, the payment block is stored as:

  • Field: PaymentBlockingReason the payment block key
  • It is available on the Operational Journal Entry Item / DebtorItem/CreditorItem structures

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/efabeff3bf8b4066ac03f0965d0a9327.html

Standard API that can change this:

  • API name (business): Journal Entry Change (Asynchronous)
  • Inbound service: JournalEntryBulkChangeRequest_In (SOAP)
  • Communication scenario: Finance Posting Integration (SAP_COM_0002)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/6b39bd1d0e5e4099a5b65d835c29c696/5792333ddf3c47eaad4314b071dfd684.html

The Finance API documentation explicitly describes this service as the way to change journal entry data and notes that it can be extended with custom fields as well

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/c3833c31e7724a79b23e4273290f3e2e.html

The Operational Journal Entry Item help lists PaymentBlockingReason as a field in the structure used together with the Journal Entry APIs

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/efabeff3bf8b4066ac03f0965d0a9327.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/b978f98fc5884ff2aeb10c8fdeb8a43b/a524c714dcaf4bbc847c9aa584e10a40.html

Summary: Yes, you can toggle the payment block on AR open items via SOAP using Journal Entry Change (Asynchronous)

Question 3.
Answer: Yes

Standard OData API:

  • API name (business): Payment Advice (A2X)
  • Technical service name: API_PAYMENT_ADVICE_SRV
  • Protocol: OData V2
  • Communication scenario: Finance ‚Äì Payment Advice Integration (SAP_COM_0331)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4f22209d1f5d4bd79c4a55017608b51b/b448d39b85dd4da6baf28e8c818f0e53.html

To register (create) a payment advice:

  • Send POST to
    /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PAYMENT_ADVICE_SRV/A_PaymentAdvice
    with payload including PaymentAdviceType, CompanyCode, PaymentAdviceNumber, etc.

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4f22209d1f5d4bd79c4a55017608b51b/5b8b271ca8004116bef1fe2c462076b0.html

The same service exposes entity sets for Payment Advice and Payment Advice Line Item and the Operations for Payment Advice documentation lists the standardCRUD operations

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4f22209d1f5d4bd79c4a55017608b51b/6fc19bf0be0d4c3891e154f3e2b88eb6.html

There is also a SOAP API:

  • Payment Advice Create (PaymentAdviceNotification_In)
  • Also under the Finance Payment Advice Integration (SAP_COM_0331)

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/4f22209d1f5d4bd79c4a55017608b51b/dbc3550ceaa4431ebda046cba88086fb.html

In Public Cloud the documentation about Automatic Payment Advice Processing explicitly refers to both Payment Advice (A2X) and Payment Advice Create as the standard integration options

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/918bca53037f408f91a2295d04ac16bc/577f55d53e544fc0ae362aed52c5af39.html

Summary:

  1. BP master + extension fields:
    Yes, Business Partner (A2X) OData API API_BUSINESS_PARTNER with custom fields enabled via Custom Fields
  2. AR open item payment block toggle:
    Yes, via Journal Entry Change (Asynchronous) SOAP (JournalEntryBulkChangeRequest_In, scenario SAP_COM_0002). No AR-specific OData API, but line-item PaymentBlockingReason is supported there
  3. Payment advice registration:
    Yes, Payment Advice (A2X) OData API API_PAYMENT_ADVICE_SRV (scenario SAP_COM_0331) and optionally SOAP Payment Advice Create

Best Regards,

Dawid
